body: Shivering in the morning chill, as they wait for a graffiti-covered storefront to open, are a woman who has lost her food stamps, a family that has become homeless, aliens who fear deportation. For almost 20 years the Citizens Advice Bureau, in the Tremont area of the Bronx, has provided assistance so its easily intimidated clients need not look
title: Cuts Threaten Charities of Last Resort

body: The day after Christmas of 1989, Brian L. began running through the halls of the clinic where he worked, ranting and screaming at the staff, demanding to be hospitalized. "I just couldn't stand the idea of going home for the holidays -- that year was really bad for me," Brain remembered last week. "I was misusing my medication. At the hospital, I
title: Finding Help After Leaving a World of Madness

body: Confronted with five recent murders in the city's biggest mob war in three decades, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office rolled out its legal artillery yesterday and summoned a parade of reputed mobsters, trying to get them to do what the Mafia hardly ever does -- talk about it. Collars up, heads lowered, faces blank behind sunglasses, a few
title: Brooklyn's Mob War Interrupted With a Quiet Day in Court

body: A 17-year-old Brooklyn high school student with a group of friends returning home from a basketball game was shot and killed on a subway platform in Manhattan yesterday evening, apparently after one of the youths bumped into another teen-ager and an angry dispute erupted, the police said. The student, Trevor Murriell, of 47 Wilson Avenue in
title: Youth Is Killed in Subway Fight

body: The broadening civil war for control of the Colombo organized-crime family yesterday claimed the life of an innocent victim, an 18-year-old youth working in a Brooklyn bagel shop who the police said was shot to death when he was mistaken for someone else. About 20 minutes earlier, the 21-year-old son of a reputed Colombo soldier was dropped off at
title: Killing Is Tied To Mafia War In Brooklyn

body: A 30-year-old man was shot in the back of the head as hung a Christmas garland on the door of his Brooklyn home Friday -- the latest victim of a struggle for control of the Colombo crime family, law-enforcement officials said yesterday. The man, Vincent Fusaro, was shot once in the head at 3:55 P.M. as he hung the garland on the door of his home at
title: BROOKLYN SLAYING TIED TO MOB FEUD

body: A 30-year-old man was shot to death yesterday in his driveway in Brooklyn, the police said. The man, Vincent Fusaro, of 310 Bay 11th Street in Bensonhurst, was shot once in the back of his head, the police said. His body was found near his black Lincoln Continental shortly before 4 P.M., Officer Andrew McInnis said. The police had no suspects or
title: Man, 30, Shot to Death

body: AT first it was just a novelty, something even Jayne Mansfield could do. Then it blossomed into the full-scale excitement of Beatlemania and the intensive mellowness of the hippie years. Later on it evolved into disco, rap and the decadence of heavy metal, and it became a slick commercial fixture on the video screen. Now it's where none of its
title: Critic's Notebook; Is It Time, Already, To Put Rock In a Museum?

body: In an incident similar to a robbery just six days ago, a jewelry store owner was boxed in by two cars as he pulled off a Brooklyn highway yesterday afternoon and then was robbed of $200,000 in jewels by a group of men, one of them holding a machine gun, the police said. A police spokesman, Officer Andrew McInnis, said that George Greenberg, 42

title: His Two Worlds Are Worlds Apart

title: Metropolitan Diary

body: THERE are days and ways that New York City seems like not that nice a place to be. Winters are the worst. The wind whistles wildly down the avenues, slaps you on the cheeks like a spurned lover and leaves your eyes watering pitifully. No matter how cold the air, the streets are filled with dirty slush. You dream of Florida, but you're lucky to
title: HOLIDAYS; Things That Melt the Humbuggiest Heart

title: Teen-Ager Kills Friend in Dispute Over Burglary

title: PARKS; New York's True Nature Is, Yes, Leafy

body: AT once a densely and diversely populated chunk of New York and a complex tangle of stereotypes and myths, Brooklyn evokes many images to the world beyond its famous bridge. It's the Dodgers and "The Honeymooners," the faded, honky-tonk luster of Coney Island and the elegance of Brooklyn Heights, and, sadly, the violence and racial tensions now
title: The Brooklyn Cookbook: Mix Ethnic Attitudes and Memories

body: A tiny minority of New York City voters quietly capped a decade of contentious legal challenges and government overhaul yesterday by nominating candidates whose victories in November will dramatically expand black and Hispanic representation on the newly invigorated City Council. They will change the Council's complexion, but not necessarily its
title: PRIMARY DAY; Council's New Era Takes Shape in New York Vote

body: Chris Hasson says he has been a permanent fixture at the Jacob Riis Park beach for 18 years, from his first visit at 4 years old, through occasional spying trips to the nudist section of the beach as a teen-ager, to his three forays a week with his friends today. "We're the cleanest beach around," Mr. Hasson said, adding that Coney Island, the New
title: Giving Riis, the Forgotten Park, a Better Image

body: An article on Tuesday about an explosion in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, misidentified a spokeswoman for Lutheran Medical Center. She is Maryteresa McKenna. The article also misstated the number of explosion victims admitted to the hospital. It was three, not four.
title: Corrections

body: A buildup of natural gas probably caused the explosion and fire that killed three people and injured 31 in two Brooklyn apartment buildings on Monday, fire officials said yesterday. For much of the day, rescue workers searched the rubble for a man they believed to be missing, but by evening they had halted the search, and officials said that
title: Natural Gas Buildup Blamed for Brooklyn Blast

body: A 72-year-old Brooklyn woman leaving a grocery store was hit yesterday by a bullet intended for a young man who was also wounded in the shooting the police said. The woman, Connie Braccia, was struck in the chest by the gunfire outside 790 13th Avenue in Bay Ridge at 3:30 P.M. The wounded man, who was involved in the fight that led to the shooting,
title: Bystander Shot in Brooklyn

body: Three people were killed and at least 34 others were injured when an explosion followed by a huge fireball virtually destroyed two three-story brick apartment buildings in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, last night. Fire and police officials said the badly burned bodies of two victims, both believed to be women, were removed from the rubble. Two other people,
title: Three Killed, Dozens Hurt In Explosion

body: SOVIET TURMOIL A6-10 The national Congress was stunned when President Gorbachev and the leaders of 10 republics proposed to transfer all central authority to themselves and a legislative council until a new union can be formed. A1 News analysis: The surprise accord is clearly a gamble to prevent the existing union from tumbling in on itself. But
title: NEWS SUMMARY

Dinkins says Officer Paul Perricone is a hero, but the 23-year-old rookie, assigned to the 86th Precinct in Brooklyn, says he was "just a cop doing his job" when he searched for survivors in a burning building destroyed by an explosion last night on 86th Street in Bay Ridge. "We were around the corner when we heard the explosion," he
title: Officer, Just 'Doing His Job,' Is Praised as Brooklyn Hero

body: As a result of the racial gerrymandering that produced New York City's new Council districts, only one-fifth of next week's primaries are between major candidates from different racial or ethnic groups. But questions of race have not faded into the background, particularly in the districts where no one group predominates and in two contests where
title: In Some Council Contests, It's Still Us Against Them

body: The crime was ordinary; the suspect was anything but. A 70-year-old woman was mugged on Friday night by a man who grabbed her pocketbook as she returned to her home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. The man, the police said yesterday, was a police officer. The officer, James Carey, 36, was arraigned yesterday on charges of second-degree robbery
title: Policeman Charged in Robbery

body: A 65-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday in the shooting death of his landlord and the wounding of the landlord's live-in companion after an argument at their home, the police said. The suspect, whose name was not immediately released by the police, was captured in a rear bedroom of the house in the Bay Ridge section after the police
title: Brooklyn Landlord Shot to Death

body: Two men who were sought by the police for a murder and the abduction of a Methodist priest in Brooklyn on the same night were arrested on Friday, the police said yesterday. The men, Marc Asher, 31 years old, of Bay 35th Street in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, and Richard Springer, 38, of 252 51st Street in the Sunset Park section, were
title: Two Men Held in Two Killings

body: Three burned-out steel piers stand like eerily twisted skeletons in Upper New York Bay as teen-agers swim past the rusted shell of a half-submerged Chevy Cutlass off the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn. Just to the north, beyond the stench of the Gowanus Canal and a huge, unused grain terminal, a short-lived Port Authority project called Fishport
title: Development Not Even a Contender on Brooklyn's Waterfront

body: It had been a good collar. Two police officers on patrol in Brooklyn had stopped a car for a traffic infraction and discovered that they had caught three suspects in a burglary that had occurred only minutes before. But like a story line on "Hill Street Blues," where events do not always happen as planned, things started to go awry rather quickly.
title: A Sharp Arrest, Some Gunshots, Then an Escape

body: Hussein Jaber, a Palestinian who moved from Jerusalem to Brooklyn 12 years ago, has creatively adapted himself to life in Sunset Park -- one of New York City's most ethnically diverse neighborhoods -- by hanging a sign in his bodega's window, which caters to the area's large Hispanic population, saying "Mexican grocery." A few blocks to the north,
title: Neighborhood Politics: Choosing the Council - An occasional look at the races for New York's new City Council; Varied Interests Vie to Represent Brooklyn District

body: New York City detectives are looking for two suspects who they believe carried out a 14-hour robbery spree in Brooklyn in which they shot three people, killing two of them and wounding the third, a Methodist minister. One of the slain victims was a retired New York police sergeant on his way to work; the other was a Brooklyn resident shot a few
title: Suspects Sought in Shootings of 3 During Crime Spree in Brooklyn

body: In recent summers, men have headed to the beach clad in snug bikini trunks, feet bare or shod in loose-fitting flip-flops. But in the summer of 1991, snug trunks are outnumbered by loose-fitting briefs. And it's the new beach shoes of choice that are worn snug. Nike's Aqua Gear collection of coordinated swimwear and water sport shoes has kept
title: Flashy New Swimwear for Feet as Well as Bodies

body: New York City detectives believe that two recent shootings during seemingly random robberies in Brooklyn were the work of two men, who are still at large and "armed and dangerous." Two of the victims were killed and one seriously wounded. The slain victims were a retired New York police sergeant on his way to work and a Brooklyn resident shot a few
title: Police Seeking Suspects in 3 Brooklyn Shootings

body: Would Henry James have described "summer afternoon" as the two most beautiful words in the English language if he had been in these parts yesterday? Ha! Not if he had been among the thousands of people who filed sullenly past the intersection of Broadway and 46th Street at 8 A.M. It was hazy, already sweltering and the billowing emission from a
title: Finish the Phrase, New York: Is It (Blank) Enough for You?

body: Priests, politicians, nuns and hundreds of others jammed a Roman Catholic church in Brooklyn yesterday for the funeral of Bishop Francis J. Mugavero, the retired head of the Brooklyn Diocese, who was eulogized as a man who spent his life loving, giving and sharing. "Today, Brooklyn's legend of kindness is laid to rest," Anthony Cardinal Bevilacqua,
title: Mugavero Is Eulogized as a 'Legend of Kindness'

body: The chairlift runs up the mountain, ski trails are open and the base lodge is full of people. But one thing is missing: snow. In summer it offers an array of activities from music festivals to
title: Sunday Outing; No Snow, But Hunter Mountain Is Busy Anyway

body: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero, who in his 22 years as the head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn combined staunch liberalism and a fierce loyalty to the Vatican, died yesterday at the age of 77. The Bishop, who retired in February 1990, died of a heart attack while vacationing in East Hampton, L.I., said Frank DeRosa, the spokesman for the
title: Francis J. Mugavero, 77, Is Dead; Was Bishop of Brooklyn 22 Years

body: If you and your family are seeking an out-of-city experience -- without really wanting to leave New York -- a trip to the Staten Island Zoo might well be pleasing. Set in a lush eight-acre park in West Brighton, the Staten Island Zoo is a little jewel that features petting animals, pony rides, a tropical rain forest and an aquarium with such
title: Sunday Outing; On S.I., Rattlers, Sharks, Otters, etc.

body: Nate Snead was repelled by a "long green thing" inside his tent. It was a lizard. Jon Danielson was worried that it was going to rain. It did. And Brian Jennings wondered if there was a spot to go swimming. There wasn't. With endless questions and boundless enthusiasm, the members of Boy Scout Troop 100 from Governors Island were on their first
title: The Toughening of Scout Troop 100

body: A smoldering fire apparently caused by firecrackers killed three people in their Brooklyn home early yesterday morning after what fire officials described as one of the most raucous and dangerous Fourth of July's in memory. The man, 57-year-old John Antonelli, his wife, Marie, 56, and his mother, Mary, 88, died as they tried to escape what
title: Fireworks Believed Cause of Blaze That Kills Three

body: Giuliani Maneuverings Rudolph W. Giuliani, who prematurely announced his 1993 mayoral candidacy to a gossip columnist at a cocktail party and then backtracked on his statement last week, is nevertheless laying the groundwork for a City Hall run by taking sides in an unusual struggle for control of the comatose Brooklyn Republican organization. The
title: Political Talk

body: AS party concepts go, this one was a trifle formal: guests were asked to wear the clothes they were married in. But it all came off without a hitch (that having been taken care of some time ago). On a photo-album June day, about 150 no-longer-blushing brides and 150 not-very-nervous grooms turned out in wedding dresses, morning suits and various
title: Here Comes the Bride. But Wait. Here Comes Another One.

body: From house to house the woman went with a heart-wrenching tale. Her little boy, 7-year-old Joey Lupa, had died of leukemia and there was no money for a proper burial. She cried and shared her sorrows with the people who came to the doors. "Would you give, please?" she asked. And people all over Brooklyn and Queens did, donating at least $25,000 --
title: No Needy Mother, Just a Con Artist, Brooklyn Police Say

body: The Box is back. Pale green with brown crosshatching, the Ebinger's cake box is stacked on the shelves of New York City supermarkets. Shoppers have gasped and paled at its resurrection. For them, after nearly two decades in an Ebingerless desert, The Box is manna. The good old days are back! Maybe. . . . For those who grew up in Brooklyn, when
title: The Cake Box From Heaven (Brooklyn, of Course) Is Back

body: THERE is too much to see in New York City and it is all moving too fast and there isn't enough time and there never will be. Groucho Marx once said that when it is 9:30 in New York, it is 1937 in Los Angeles. The curious thing is that New York remains New York in essential ways. The architecture reflects successive visions of brilliant new worlds;
title: ATTRACTIONS; What Sights to See, Big Time (and Small)

body: Anthony E. Maglio, a retired Criminal Court judge in Brooklyn, died on Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Brooklyn. He died of cancer, his family said. Judge Maglio, who began a two-decade career on the bench as a magistrate an 1950, gained a reputation as a crusader against street crime. But, coincidentally, in
title: Anthony Maglio, 79, A Retired Judge, Dies

body: No one seemed to get it right away, but something hairy was happening at the Oscar de la Renta fur show yesterday. The first four people down the runway at the Parsons School of Design wore stretch bodysuits and flesh-toned panty-bra sets -- and the only animal fur they had on was their own. "We'd rather go naked than wear furs," said a sign they
title: Patterns

body: The bedroom's lace curtains rustle in a cool spring breeze, filtering dots of sunlight onto a four-poster bed. Like hundreds of other bed-and-breakfasts throughout America, the appeal of Donald Kurz-Fiedeke's small hostelry is its 19th-century charm, its whiff of romance. But just beyond the curtains and a well-tended garden, laundry hangs from
title: Brooklyn Tells Tourists, Yo! Don't Overlook Us

body: James Diodato reacted within seconds yesterday, stripped and jumped into the swirling, cold waters under the Verrazano Narrows Bridge. For more than half an hour, the 23-year-old former Marine tried to reach a 14-year-old boy flailing against the current and screaming, "Help me, I'm going to die." There was terror in the boy's face, Mr. Diodato
title: Daring Rescue Attempt Ends Tragically for Boy

body: Rich Kotite is the new head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles. But on Saturday night he was going to be just one of the guys again, at the Poly Prep class of '61 reunion in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. As he drove up the Jersey Turnpike after leading the Eagles through an off-season mini-camp, Kotite seemed transformed by memories of the Brooklyn sidewalks.
title: FOOTBALL; An Eagle With Wings Spanning Over Brooklyn

body: The commission charged with redistricting the New York City Council is ensnared in a tangle of racial and party politics just three days before it is to present its vision for a legislature that would represent the city's sweeping ethnic diversity. The Districting Commission, created under the 1989 City Charter and heralded as the new and
title: OLD FEUDS TANGLE NEW CITY COUNCIL AS DEADLINE NEARS

body: A 65-year-old doctor who neighbors described as a dignified and caring man was shot and killed Saturday night in Brooklyn when he tried to prevent a mugger from grabbing his wife's purse as the couple walked home, the police said. The doctor, Samuel Seibel, was shot once in the chest just after 11 P.M. in front of 225 78th Street in the Bay Ridge
title: Doctor Is Killed Trying to Block Purse Snatching

body: The slide that began three years ago on Wall Street has now ricocheted throughout the city's economy, claiming jobs in everything from banking to auto repair. As the recession continues to deepen, tens of thousands of New Yorkers are discovering its pain, finding themselves in unemployment lines that are growing longer and ever-more democratic.
title: All Walks of Life Now Converge In New York City's Jobless Lines

body: A 68-year-old Brooklyn man who had waged a campaign against drug dealers was run over and killed by a furious van driver this week, the police said. The man's family and neighbors said the killing was in retaliation for his persistence in ordering drug dealers, addicts and prostitutes off the block. The killing on Tuesday night crushed the spirit
title: Enemy of Local Drug Dealers Is Killed on a Brooklyn Street

body: The independent body charged with creating 51 new New York City Council districts gave the first glimpse of what those possibilities could be yesterday, setting the stage for a political revolution that could for the first time send to the Council previously unrepresented groups like Asian-Americans and gay people. At a news conference, the New
title: 34 Options Are Given for New Council

body: Two people sat precariously on top of an abutment of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge late Tuesday night, discussing which was better: living or dying. One, a 24-year-old named Irwin Cuevas, saw his marriage crumbling and wanted to jump 200 feet to his death; the other, a frail 24-year-old off-duty police officer named Yolanda Lugo, said death was too
title: Talk of Living or Dying Atop a Bridge Abutment

body: New York City jail guards strapped electronic transmitters on the left ankles of two inmates and then opened the gates for them. As the men strolled from the Brooklyn House of Detention last month they became the first to be released under a city program in which defendants awaiting trial are placed under house arrest and monitored by electronic
title: New York Tests Electronic Ball and Chain

body: ALTHOUGH people of many ethnic backgrounds live in the 4.2-square-mile Brooklyn neighborhood of Sunset Park, residents and business owners say the community is more a stew pot than a melting pot. "Each ethnic group is proud of its heritage," said Ross M. Branka, a real-estate lawyer who has practiced in the area more than 20 years. "So we have
title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Sunset Park

body: A New York City police officer and a correction officer have been suspended a shooting on Thursday night in which the correction officer fired into a vehicle, injuring a man, the authorities said yesterday. Spokesmen for the Police and Correction Departments said that the officers were off duty at the time and that no charges had been filed against
title: 2 Off-Duty Officers Suspended in Shooting

body: In 1935, Police Commissioner Lewis Valentine of New York City interrupted a line-up to berate the arresting officers. Why, he demanded, had they brought in a murder suspect without first "mussing him up?" Commissioner Valentine's vigor was widely applauded; he was retained as commissioner for a decade. If, as Dr. James J. Fyfe, an American
title: Metro Matters; Brutal Question: Police Violence, Public Trust

body: The signs of social change and the transformation of a community are often subtle, sometimes brutal and occasionally bizarre. Into this last category falls the former Atlantic restaurant, a popular diner that for decades catered to the many Norwegian-Americans of the Sunset Park and Bay Ridge sections of Brooklyn. Today, above the entrance on
title: In Brooklyn, Wontons, Not Lapskaus

body: Miguel Montero, the star center of the George Washington High School basketball team in Washington Heights, longs to hear the roar of the crowd. But when Stuyvesant High School's team visited his school one afternoon recently, most of his 29 points were greeted by only polite applause. Just 17 fans attended the game, and they were made to sit in a
title: Many High Schools Bar Basketball Game Fans

body: Rumpelmayer's The age of the palatial ice-cream parlor has all but disappeared, like the last spoonful of a hot-fudge sundae. A few winsome artifacts remain in the New York metropolitan area that are fun for kids (or adults): Eddie's Sweet Shop in Forest Hills, Queens; Hoft's Luncheonette in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx; Hinsch's in the
title: Diner's Journal

body: Mothers from Bay Ridge and gay men from Manhattan, doctors treating AIDS and patients suffering from the disease, rabbis and priests, parents and students all came to the Board of Education yesterday to plead, reason, shout and harangue on a question that has divided many in New York: Should the city's high schools provide condoms to their
title: Desperation And Anger In Debate On Condoms

body: State Attorney General Robert Abrams has obtained an injunction freezing the assets of Stockbridge Funding, a mortgage banking corporation that is being investigated for possibly bilking investors, mostly Polish-Americans in the New York metropolitan area, of as much as $100 million. In a statement, he said he "believes that Stockbridge was
title: 'Ponzi Scheme' Is Cited As Assets Are Frozen

body: Many Foods, One Shape The shape of foods to come, for the next week or so, is the heart. Pizzas, cheeses, cookies, candies, cakes, tarts, raviolis and breads are being designed for Valentine's Day. At the Ambassador Grill in the United Nations Plaza Hotel, they'll even be carving foie gras into heart shapes. All day on Feb. 14, Trattoria dell'Arte,
title: Food Notes

body: THE Fort Hamilton enclave of Brooklyn's Bay Ridge section hasn't changed much since 1930, the last year of a housing boom that had been started by the 1915 extension of the New York City subway system to Brooklyn. Many of the stucco or brick private homes built in those years have remained in the same families. "In most of Brooklyn, people move
title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Fort Hamilton

body: Maria Olejnik came to the United States three years ago with $50 in her pocket and the dream of saving enough to build a better life for her husband and the two small daughters she left behind in Poland. She and about 1,500 other people -- many of them Polish immigrants living in the New York metropolitan area -- placed their faith and millions of
title: Polish Emigres Lose Savings and Dreams

body: AN increasing number of sellers in today's difficult market are finding it worthwhile to have their homes inspected to find problems that might put off a buyer. Such inspections often can turn up conditions, like leaky windows or damp in the basement, that the owner has lived with for years but that might kill a sale to a demanding buyer. "I've
title: Talking: Inspections; Spotting Trouble for Sellers

body: "O.K.," said Nate, peering down his horn-rimmed bifocals, "you're a man. Do you just love to shop around for clothes? Of course not! Men aren't missionaries always seeking new places. Men want a good store. Good value. Good treatment. Good talk -- sports, politics, maybe markets. And then outta there. Am I right? So, that's me, Nate Friedman,
title: Our Towns; Nate the Clothier: Bidding Farewell In Way That Fits

body: Cipe Pineles Burtin, who broke the sex barrier at the Art Directors Club of New York by becoming a member in 1943 and went on to become the first woman inducted into its Hall of Fame, died on Thursday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. She was 82 years old and lived in Stony Point, N.Y. Mrs. Burtin, who worked under the name Cipe Pineles
title: Cipe Pineles Burtin Is Dead at 82; First Woman in Art Directors Club

body: John T. O'Hagan, who served simultaneously as chief of the New York City Fire Department and as Fire Commissioner in the mid-70's, died on Wednesday at his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He was 65 years old. He died of cardiopulmonary arrest because of widespread cancer, which he had been fighting since July 1989, said his son, Michael.
title: John T. O'Hagan Is Dead at 65; Fire Commissioner in the 1970's

body: John T. O'Hagan, who served simultaneously as chief of the New York City Fire Department and as Fire Commissioner in the mid-70's, died yesterday at his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. title: John T. O'Hagan, 65, Fire Chief And Fire Commissioner in the 70's

body: New York City environmental officials yesterday tested the waters of New York Harbor for pollution damage after a leak of 654,00 gallons of treated sewage on Sunday morning from a city-owned barge. In heavy fog, the 375-foot barge, the Lemon Creek, collided with a tanker carrying molasses, opening a hole in two of the barge's 10 sewage sludge
title: Barge Collision Spills Sewage Sludge Off Brooklyn
